Test.Comment: Dropping normal indexes Unique index names(drop index indexname)

Statement.CallString: create table tab1(int1 integer, int2 integer, int3 integer, char1 varchar(100), char2 varchar(100), char3 varchar(100), char4 varchar(100), char5 varchar(100))
create index ind1b on tab1(int2, char2)
create index ind1f on tab1(int2 asc)
create index ind1g on tab1(char4 desc)
create index ind1h on tab1(int3 asc, char3 desc)
create unique index ind1i on tab1(char5)
create unique index ind1j on tab1(char3, int1)
create unique index ind1k on tab1(char1 asc, int3 desc)
create unique index ind1l on tab1(int1, int2, int3 asc, char1 desc ,char2 desc,char3 asc)
select count(indexname) from indexes where tablename = 'TAB1'
select count(indexname) from indexes where tablename = 'TAB1'

Test.Comment: Dropping normal indexes non-unique index names(drop index indexname on tablename)

Statement.CallString: create table tab1(int1 integer, int2 integer, int3 integer, char1 varchar(100), char2 varchar(100), char3 varchar(100), char4 varchar(100), char5 varchar(100))
create table tab2(int1 integer, int2 integer, int3 integer, char1 varchar(100), char2 varchar(100), char3 varchar(100), char4 varchar(100), char5 varchar(100))
create index ind1b on tab1(int2, char2)
create index ind1b on tab2(int2, char2)
create index ind1f on tab1(int2 asc)
create index ind1f on tab2(int2 asc)
create index ind1g on tab1(char4 desc)
create index ind1g on tab2(char4 desc)
create index ind1h on tab1(int3 asc, char3 desc)
create index ind1h on tab2(int3 asc, char3 desc)
create unique index ind1i on tab1(char5)
create unique index ind1i on tab2(char5)
create unique index ind1j on tab1(char3, int1)
create unique index ind1j on tab2(char3, int1)
create unique index ind1k on tab1(char1 asc, int3 desc)
create unique index ind1k on tab2(char1 asc, int3 desc)
create unique index ind1l on tab1(int1, int2, int3 asc, char1 desc ,char2 desc,char3 asc)
create unique index ind1l on tab2(int1, int2, int3 asc, char1 desc ,char2 desc,char3 asc)
select count(indexname) from indexes where tablename = 'TAB1' or tablename = 'TAB2'

Test.Comment: Altering columnnames after creating indexes( internal mode)

Statement.CallString: create table tab29(int1 integer, int2 integer, char1 char(100), char2 char(200))
create index ind29c on tab29(int2, char2)
select count(*) from indexes where tablename = 'TAB29'
select count(indexname) from indexcolumns where tablename = 'TAB29' and (columnname like 'INT_' or columnname like 'CHAR_')
select count(indexname) from indexcolumns where tablename = 'TAB29' and (columnname like 'INT_A' or columnname like 'CHAR_A')

create table tab387b(int1 numeric(10),int2 numeric(10),float1 float(38), char1 char(100), char2 varchar(100))

create index ind387b on tab387b(float1, char2, int2)
rename index ind387a on tab387a to 2ind
rename index ind387 on tab387a to _ind387
rename index ind387 on tab387a to ichbineinindex387amit33stellenimN
create table tab72(int1 integer, int2 integer, char1 varchar(100), char2 varchar(100))
select count(indexname) from indexes where tablename = 'TAB72'

create index index456b on tab456(int2 asc , char1 desc )

select count(sort) from indexcolumns where tablename = 'TAB456' and indexname like 'INDEX456%' and sort = 'DESC'

Test.Comment: Negative Test: its impossible to create two indexes for the same column (Columns defined as PK are indexed automatically)

Statement.CallString: create table tab134 (int1 integer, int2 integer Primary key,int3 integer,int4 integer,int5 integer, int6 integer,int7 integer, int8 integer, int9 integer)
select count(indexname) from indexes where tablename = 'TAB134'
create table tab153(int1 integer, int2 integer, char1 varchar(100), char2 varchar(100))
create unique index ind153a on tab153(int1)
create unique index ind153b on tab153(char2)
Update tab153 set int1 = NULL where int1 = 1
Update tab153 set char2 = NULL where char2 = 'sechs'
select count(*) from tab153 where int1 is null
select count(*) from tab153 where char2 is NULL

create unique index ind216a on tab216a(int1)
create unique index ind216b on tab216b (char1)
alter table tab216c add primary key (int1)
alter table tab216d add primary key (char1)

Test.Comment: Altering the tablename after creating a index(oracle mode)

Statement.CallString: create table tab276(int1 integer, int2 integer, char1 char(100), char2 char(200))
select count(*) from indexes where tablename = 'TAB276'
select count(*) from indexes where tablename = 'TAB276A'
select count(*) from indexes where tablename = 'TAB276A'
select count(*) from indexes where tablename = 'TAB276B'
create table tab192(int1 integer, int2 integer, char1 varchar(100), char2 varchar(100))
select count(indexname) from indexes where tablename = 'TAB192'
create table tab230a(int1 numeric(10),int2 numeric(10),float1 float(38), char1 char(100), char2 varchar(100))
create table tab230b(int1 numeric(10),int2 numeric(10),float1 float(38), char1 char(100), char2 varchar(100))
create index ind230b on tab230b(float1, char2, int2)
alter index ind230 on tab230a disable
alter index ind230 on tab230b disable
select count(*) from indexes where tablename in ('TAB230A','TAB230B') and disabled = 'YES'
create table tab230a(int1 numeric(10),int2 numeric(10),float1 float(38), char1 char(100), char2 varchar(100))
create table tab230b(int1 numeric(10),int2 numeric(10),float1 float(38), char1 char(100), char2 varchar(100))
create index ind230b on tab230b(float1, char2, int2)
alter index ind230 on tab230a disable
alter index ind230 on tab230b disable
select count(*) from indexes where tablename in ('TAB230A','TAB230B') and disabled = 'YES'
alter index ind230 on tab230a enable
alter index ind230 on tab230b enable
select count(*) from indexes where tablename in ('TAB230A','TAB230B') and disabled = 'NO'

alter index ind230 on tab230b init usage

select count(indexname) from indexcolumns where tablename = 'TAB29' and (columnname like 'INT_A' or columnname like 'CHAR_A')

Test.Comment: Test: The Statements CLUSTER <cluster>, INITRANS <integer>, MAXTRANS <integer>, TABLESPACE <tablespace>, STORAGE <storage_clause>, PCTFREE <integer> and NOSORT are not supported by SAP DB. Nevertheless syntax is accepted by SAP DB, but does not have any consequences.

Statement.CallString: create table tab702 (int1 integer, int2 integer,int3 integer,int4 integer,int5 integer, int6 integer,int7 integer, int8 integer, int9 integer)
create index index1 on tab702(int1) INITRANS 1
create index index2 on tab702(int2) maxtrans 24325
create index index3 on tab702(int3) Tablespace halleluja
create index index4 on tab702(int4) Storage ( initial 123 K next 3453 M minextents 43 maxextents 3452 PCTINCREASE 345 optimal 353 Freelists 35344 Freelist groups 3534 )
create index index5 on tab702(int5) PCTFREE 9
create index index6 on tab702(int6) NOSORT
create index index7 on tab702(int7) initrans 1 NOSORT PCTFREE 9

create index index8 on tab702(int8) maxtrans 24325 Tablespace halleluja Storage ( initial 123 K next 3453 M minextents 43 maxextents 3452 PCTINCREASE 345 optimal 353 Freelists 35344 Freelist groups 3534 )

create index index9 on tab702(int9) maxtrans 24325 Tablespace halleluja Storage ( initial 123 K next 3453 M minextents 43 maxextents 3452 PCTINCREASE 345 optimal 353 Freelists 35344 Freelist groups 3534 ) initrans 1 NOSORT PCTFREE 9
select count(indexname) from indexes where tablename='TAB702'
create table tab374(int1 integer, int2 integer, char1 char(100), char2 char(200))
create unique index index374a on tab374(int1 asc, char2)
create unique index index374b on tab374(int2, char1 asc )
create unique index index374c on tab374(int1 asc)
create unique index index374d on tab374(char2 asc)
create unique index ind374x on tab374(char2 asc, int1 asc)
select count(indexname) from indexes where tablename = 'TAB374'
select count(*) from indexcolumns where tablename = 'TAB374' and SORT = 'ASC'
select count(*) from indexcolumns where tablename = 'TAB374' and SORT = 'DESC'

select count(sort) from indexcolumns where tablename = 'TAB456' and indexname like 'INDEX456%' and sort = 'DESC'

Error.ErrorMessage: [-1009]: Too many named indexes for this table

Test.Comment: Negative test. No duplicate Index names on one table. The Indexname is not unique. Oracle uses Unique indexnames. To drop a index use "Drop index indexname on tablename"
